questions.uddipok:
Answer the following questions:
(a) What does WHO say about adolescence?
(b) How many adolescents are boys and how many are girls in Bangladesh?
(c) How is the condition of the adolescent girls in Bangladesh?
(d) What is the legal age of marriage for boys and girls in our country?
(e) When do the boys become ready for marriage?

sub_questions.explanation:
(a)
The World Health Organization (WHO) defines adolescence as the period of life between 10 and 19 years of age. This stage marks the transition from childhood to adulthood, characterized by significant physical, emotional, and social development. Adolescents experience rapid growth and undergo various changes that influence their health, behavior, and interactions with society.
(b)
According to the 2022 Bangladesh Census, the population of adolescents aged 10–14 is approximately 16.6 million, with 8.5 million boys and 7.8 million girls. For the 15–19 age group, there are about 16.5 million adolescents, comprising 8.1 million boys and 8.5 million girls. In total, adolescents make up about 28.8% of Bangladesh's population, with a near-equal distribution between boys and girls.
(c)
Adolescent girls in Bangladesh face several challenges
Child Marriage : Approximately 51% of girls in Bangladesh are married before the age of 18, making it one of the highest rates globally.
Education : While enrollment rates for girls have improved, many still face barriers to completing secondary education, especially in rural areas.
Health Risks : Early pregnancies pose significant health risks, with many adolescent girls becoming mothers before reaching adulthood.
Violence and Abuse : A significant number of adolescent girls experience physical or sexual violence, often within intimate relationships.
These issues hinder their development and access to opportunities, perpetuating cycles of poverty and inequality.
(d)
In Bangladesh, the legal age for marriage is 18 for girls and 21 for boys, as stipulated by the Child Marriage Restraint Act of 2017. However, the law includes provisions that allow for exceptions under certain circumstances, such as parental consent and court approval, which have been criticized for potentially undermining efforts to prevent child marriage.
(e)
While the legal age for marriage is 21 for boys in Bangladesh, readiness for marriage is influenced by various factors beyond age, including emotional maturity, financial stability, and societal expectations. Cultural norms often dictate that men should be established in their careers and capable of supporting a family before marriage. However, these expectations can vary widely across different communities and regions within the country.

questions.uddipok:
Write a summary of the following text.
The famous Greek philosopher Aristotle said, "Man is by nature a social animal." What he meant was that man, by instinct, seeks company of others and establishes relationships, much like most animals of the wild, for companionship and for physical and emotional support. Unlike the animals however, man's relationships give meaning to his existence and inspires him to do well in education, in workplace or in a profession that he pursues.
Relationships are of different kinds. Some are familial and intimate, formed by blood and by marriage; some are social like the ones we have with friends and some are made in school where we, form close bonds with classmates and teachers. Relationships can also be fostered in workplace, which may quickly change from professional to social. There are relationships also between human beings and animals, between children and their toys that they cannot part with.
All these relationships keep us close to each other and provide us all kinds of support, love and affection. A person who has no family feels the pain of loneliness and isolation. There is no one to laugh or cry with him/her. When we share our joy with someone, it simply redoubles, and when we suffer a loss and someone shares our sorrow, it lessens. Relationships are thus needed for our emotional health.
To build relationships, we need to have trust and respect for each other, and love where this is needed. We cannot be selfish and possessive if we want to establish an effective relationship. But quite often we see people quarrelling and fighting with each other which only brings misery and loss to all.

sub_questions.explanation: The passage portrays the fact that human beings naturally develop different types of relationships through trust, respect and love. Relationships are formed by blood or marriage, in educational institutions or workplaces, etc. Relationships give meaning to our existence and inspire us to perform well in every stage. Moreover, relationships fill our life with love, support, and endearment. Lonely and isolated people cannot share their joy or sorrow. Through sharing, happiness increases, and sorrows decreases. Hence, relationships are essential for mental health. However, relationships with selfishness and possessiveness are detrimental to mental health and cause sufferings.

questions.uddipok:
Rearrange the following sentences to make a coherent order.
(i) Next day all the servants submitted their sticks to the judge.
(ii) The judge also said that the stick of the thief would increase by an inch.
(iii) One stick was found shortened by an inch and the thief was easily detected and sent to jail thereby.
(iv) He made a complaint before the judge.
(v) He gave all of them a stick of equal length and asked to submit the stick on the following day.
(vi) He thought that the purse had been stolen by someone of his servants.
(vii) The judge summoned all the servants and all of them denied the charge.
(viii) One day a rich man lost his purse.
(ix) The judge then hit upon a plan to detect the thief.
(x) The servants went home and everyone kept his stick as it was but the servant who stole the purse reduced the length of his stick by one inch.

sub_questions.explanation:
(viii) →(vi)→ (iv) → (vii) → (ix)→ (v)→(ii)→(x) → (i) → (iii).
One day a rich man lost his purse. He thought that the purse had been stolen by someone of his servants. He made a complaint before the judge. The judge summoned all the servants and all of them denied the charge. The judge then hit upon a plan to detect the thief. He gave all of them a stick of equal length and asked to submit the stick on the following day. The judge also said that the stick of the thief would increase by an inch. The servants went home and everyone kept his stick as it was but the servant who stole the purse reduced the length length of his stick by one inch. Next day all the servants submitted their sticks to the judge. One stick was found shortened by an inch and the thief was easily detected and sent to jail thereby.

questions.uddipok: Look at the following graph. It shows a comparative selling rate of four types of books in Ekushey Boi Mela 2016. Describe the graph-in at least 80 words. You should highlight the information and report the main features given in the graph.

sub_questions.explanation:
The bar graph presents the comparative selling rates of four types of books at the Ekushey Boi Mela in 2016. Among the categories, novels were the most sold, reaching a peak of over 4,000 copies , indicating high reader interest in fiction. Science fiction books followed, with sales of around 3,000 copies , showing strong popularity, especially among younger readers. History books had a moderate selling rate of about 2,200 copies , while poetry books were the least sold, with fewer than 500 copies .
This data suggests a clear preference for imaginative and narrative-driven literature over academic or artistic forms. The graph highlights how fiction, particularly novels and science fiction, dominated readers’ choices at the fair, whereas interest in poetry appeared significantly low.

questions.uddipok:
Read the beginning of the following story and complete it in your own way. Give a title to the story:
Parul was a school girl whose parents were landless. They were unable to bear her educational expenses. But Parul was determined ...........................

sub_questions.explanation:
Title: "Parul's Path to Education"
Parul was a school girl whose parents were landless. They were unable to bear her educational expenses. But Parul was determined to pursue her education against all odds. Every morning, she would wake up before dawn, her determination shining brighter than the rising sun. With a heart full of dreams and a mind filled with ambition, she embarked on a journey to seek knowledge, knowing that education was her ticket to a better future.
Despite the financial hardships her family faced, Parul refused to let their circumstances define her fate. She sought out every opportunity to learn, whether it was through her school's scholarship programs, part-time jobs after class, or seeking assistance from local NGOs and community organizations. Her resilience and perseverance inspired those around her, earning her the admiration and support of teachers, neighbors, and even strangers.
Parul's unwavering dedication to her studies bore fruit as she excelled academically, surpassing expectations and setting new standards for herself. Her parents, despite their struggles, beamed with pride at their daughter's achievements, realizing that education was indeed the greatest gift they could give her.
As Parul continued her journey, she became a beacon of hope for other children in similar circumstances, proving that with determination and hard work, anything is possible. Her story spread far and wide, igniting a spark of hope in the hearts of those who dared to dream.
Parul's path to education was not easy, but it was a testament to the power of perseverance, resilience, and the unwavering belief in the transformative power of education. She proved that no obstacle is too great to overcome when fueled by the fire of determination and the desire for knowledge.

questions.uddipok: Suppose, you are Samina. You received a letter from your father yesterday. In that letter, he warned you not to spend much time on Facebook. Now, write a reply to his letter.

sub_questions.explanation:
105 C, West Nakhalpara, Dhaka
05 July 2023
Dear Father,
I received your letter the day before yesterday. My joy knew no bounds to receive the sletter containing much good advice for me.
In your letter I have noticed a great worry about my study and my spending a lot of time on Facebook. But, father, you have nothing to be worried about. I am really very busy with my ensuing HSC Examination. In our college, a special coaching arrangement has been made and we have to participate (অংশগ্রহণ করা) in the scheduled coaching programmes dally. We solve our daily problems in the coaching classes. So, we need not have to bother (মাথা ঘামান) for our studies at our house. As for spending time on facebook, I spend maximum thirty minutes on Facebook daily. This is required in this age of technology. It does not hamper my studies at all, rather I learn many important things out of it. So, please don't worry in this respect. I am very conscious of my studies. We all are well here. Please take care of your health.
Yours affectionately,
Samina
